title: INEFFICIENT COLLEGES: WASTE OF TALENT
abstract: Higher education is not overlooked in the Johnson-sponsored aid-toeducation legislation, but its benefits will fall far short unless the colleges and universities do a great deal to provide more education at less cost per student.

title: FOLLOWING THE RETURNS: CUTTING CORNERS
abstract: Dissent from a popular decision always involves painful soul-searching by a judge, a legislator, or a journalist. And when the decision may claim moral justification, opposition is doubly hard. That is why this piece is written with the greatest of reluctance.

title: THIS IS OUR BUSINESS: THE 'LION'S PAW'
abstract: While both Presidential candidates may labor to prevent pre-Civil War issues from playing a part in this campaign, there is nothing they can do about the ignition of a still more remote concern—the spirit of 1776.

title: AN AMERICAN EPIC: HUNGER, PESTILENCE
abstract: This year, 1964, will see two anniversaries in the life of Herbert Hoover. He will be 90 years old in August. And, as fate decreed it, it was in August 50 years ago that Hoover gave up his career as an engineer and in the half century since he has given his entire life to the public service.

title: The Essential South: THE EISENHOWER DECLINE
abstract: OKLAHOMA City—The emergence of a young and growing Republican Party in the hitherto Democratic South may well be the salvation of the Republican cause over the nation. Indeed, it may be essential to the preservation of a national twoparty system. This is why I have attempted to study this remarkable political change during a five weeks' trip through the South this spring and also in 1963.

title: The Issues in California: WORLDWIDE OUTLOOK
abstract: LOS ANGELES—Many good citizens of California with whom I have discussed the current primary campaign deeply deplore some of the national publicity which it has received. Such embarrassments through misunderstanding of the complex nature of California politics are not new.

title: Scattered Policy-Making: DIVIDED RESPONSIBILITY
abstract: THE circumstances which have brought and still may bring the United States disastrous consequences in the Congo invite examination. Those future consequences of the U.N. adventure could be either bloody chaos and factional strife followed by Communist penetration, or complete conquest of Katanga.

title: A Money Crisis, Too: THE RECKONING
abstract: MR. CORNELIUS CITIZEN, confronted with a new national or international crisis a day, recedes from his once-exalted state as master of his government to membership in a be wildered, fearful mass of onlookers. On some issues he can give the inquiring reporter a quick answer.

title: 'Flags of Necessity': NO SUBSIDIES
abstract: ON FEB. 16, 1961, the National Labor Relations Board brushed aside the long settled policy of other Federal agencies and ruled that it would assume jurisdiction over the foreign crew of an American-owned ship registered under the Liberian flag.

title: The Disfranchised: CORRECTION BY LAW
abstract: IN THE midst of all the hand-on| heart declarations of politicians concerning the Negroes who are prevented from voting and the boasts that the right to vote has been extended by Federal law to enfranchise those people, to my knowledge nothing has been said or done by either party for 8 million voters who were unable to vote on Nov. 8.

title: Image and Inheritance: EASY TO UNDERSTAND
abstract: THIS may be a good moment to reflect upon the remarkable achievement of a young man with a single purpose who rose so fast and so soon to the prize of prizes, a Presidential nomination. The only candidacy which has ever offered a comparison with that of John Fitzgerald Kennedy was that which Marcus A. Hanna promoted for his beloved friend William McKinley over a period of eight years.

title: World Peace by Law: CONNALLY RESERVATION
abstract: As AN ideal, "world peace through law" has moved enlightened minds over many centuries. There were many prophets even before Dante wrote his De Monarchia in the fourteenth century. Three hundred years later, Hugo Grotius became the founder of modern international law.

title: The Vice Presidency: THESE ARE EXPENDABLE
abstract: RICHARD NIXON has created a significant constitutional institution out of the shell of a meaningless sinecure. Therein lies a wonderful chance for both parties to show that they are not wedded to ossified traditions about the Vice Presidency. One such tradition is that the nominee should be a bait for votes.

title: Dilemma of the Left: AN ILL-ASSORTED LOT
abstract: Now, seven weeks after witnessing the rout of the Labor Party in Britain and after visiting three other countries in Europe, it is time to appraise the political revolution which seems to be quietly moving over our Western allies. It is the ascendency of experience over experimentation, the realization of the possible over prophecy, things over ideology, and fact over fancy.

title: Curran et al. vs. U.S.A.: FAST SHIPS
abstract: THE four-day boycott of ships registered under the laws of several small nations, mentioned in this space last week, has come and gone. It was initiated for publicity purposes by the International Transport Workers' Federation, housed in a small office in London. A dud abroad, it got its most lusty support from Joseph Curran's National Maritime Union and Paul Hall's Seafarers.

title: Politicians Run a War: VACUUMS FOR STALIN
abstract: GEN. Albert C. Wedemeyer's book, "Wedemeyer Reports" (NEWSWEEK, Nov. 17), is destined to fan hot flames of controversy. For he steps on many toes—big toes, too. Through the incisive skill of a man who knew, as few others, the art and science of warfare, Wedemeyer portrays the frailties and strength of those politicians whose word was final in the war in Europe between 1942 and 1945.

title: Status of Our Teachers: SALARIES ARE GOOD
abstract: To ANTICIPATE letters about my living in an ivory tower, I shall qualify as a witness. Beginning in a one-room, eight-grade district school, I was over a considerable period engaged in grade, high-school, college, and university instruction. I know from experience the trials, troubles, and triumphs of the trade.

title: Behind the Subsidies: ROLE OF CONSUMERS
abstract: MONTPELIER, VT.—One of the richest rewards of a summer up here in the heart of the Green Mountains is contact with people in public as well as in private life who can take a cool, semidetached look at the affairs of the nation. Montpelier, one of the smaller state capitals, is rich in tradition but cosmopolitan in outlook.

title: Smith of Virginia: STATESMAN'S RECORD
abstract: IF THIS observer were to name the Most Valuable Member in this and several preceding Congresses, he would be hard put to choose between two gentlemen from Virginia, the indispensable Byrd and the man affectionately known as "Judge" Smith. Howard Worth Smith resigned a judgeship to run for Congress 28 years ago and has served continuously since.

title: Tyranny of a Majority: QUILL'S GREAT POWER
abstract: "TYRANNY consists in the wanton or inequitable use of strength by the stronger, in the use of it to do things which one equal would not attempt against another. A majority is tyrannical when it decides without hearing the minority, when it suppresses fair and temperate criticism of its own acts, when it insists upon restraining men in matters not required by the common interest, when it forces men to contribute money to objects which they disapprove and which the common interest does not demand ... tyranny lies in the wantonness of the act, a wantonness springing from the insolence which sense of overwhelming power breeds ...

title: The Score on Economy: REPUBLICAN DEFENSE
abstract: AS COOL autumn days soothe the city of Washington, members of Congress who struggled through the heat of the summer are not there to enjoy the change. They are at home facing another sort of heat, explaining their records on the issues which concern their constituents.

title: Above the Law: DEAN POUND
abstract: THERE was a medieval maxim: "Tell me the man and I will tell you the right." This meant that there was no equal justice for all, but that an individual's liability for his actions was to be determined by the class to which he belonged. The king, of course, was accountable to no law and to no authority.

title: Senator O'Mahopoly: INTERLOCKING
abstract: IN A recent speech Sen. Joseph C. O'Mahoney, perennial scourge of big business and exponent of Federal incorporation, made a surprising confession. His testimony to the efficiency of the villain in his tale, General Motors, was, he said, expressed in his personal ownership of a Cadillac.

title: A Tale of Three Secretaries
abstract: SEN. KERR SCOTT, chairman of a Senate-House subcommittee, has been conducting an investigation of certain affairs in the Department of the Interior with all of that ruthless energy once attributed to Senator McCarthy.

title: Inside Stuff
abstract: THESE days, because a Presidential election is ahead, I find in traveling hither and yon that people are bored by my musty accumulation of the lore of the past and are eagerly asking who is going to run and how and where. What, in short, is the inside dope?

title: The John Day Partnership
abstract: PORTLAND, ORE.—It may well be that the outstanding achievement of the Eisenhower Administration on the domestic front will be a Federal-local partnership plan in river development. An outstanding example would be the proposed John Day dam and power plant on the Columbia River.

title: 'Excessive Abuse'
abstract: ADDRESSING himself to the disgraceful exhibition of bias and bad manners by some of the correspondents at the President's Armistice Day press conference, Richard Wilson of the Cowles publications said: "There was an excessive abuse of the privilege of the press by newspapermen who ought to know better."

title: Salvaging Ex-Presidents
abstract: "I AM dead, dead, but in the Elysian Fields." This was the comment of Benjamin Disraeli when, at 72, he became Earl of Beaconsfield and entered the House of Lords. His promotion, however, differed from that gentle elevation to a cushioned shelf which is the tradition of the British with their superannuated statesmen.

title: A Road Away From Statism
abstract: ON A recent radio program I was asked by the moderator whether I was worried about the number of businessmen whom Eisenhower had chosen for his official family. I answered that I was not nearly so worried as I would be if I were one of the businessmen concerned.

title: Not for Sale
abstract: THIS election has proved that there was considerable difference among voters as to the meaning of the word "good" in the slogan "You never had it so good." The decision a majority made indicated that they felt that the good life means more than the goods of life.

title: The Forgotten Majority
abstract: PORTLAND, Ore.-- It was an instructive experience to observe the Democratic convention through the mediums of radio, the press, and television, while enjoying the detachment of more than 2,000 miles from the harassments of Chicago. That detachment has made it possible to appraise the issues as thoughtful Americans will appraise them in the days and weeks and months before election.

title: Rough Going Ahead
abstract: THIS piece has been written before the momentous decisions of the Republican convention have been made. It is designed to look beyond that convention to the campaign that lies ahead. Whoever the candidates may be, the Republican Party is facing rough going.

title: Japan After a Cease-Fire
abstract: IT is most fortunate for the United States as well as for Japan that the prospects are so bright for an early conclusion of a peace treaty. For Japan is suffering from two shocks that need practical and immediate relief. Apparently negotiator John Foster Dulles has done an excellent job with the treaty.

title: The Subsidy Flimflam
abstract: THE basic fraud in subsidies, now looming in Administration circles, to make food controls and rollbacks palatable to farmers and unions is part and parcel of the whole welfare-state philosophy. Powerful interests that can save or destroy the Administration are to be bought at the expense of the vast majority of taxpayers and future taxpayers and consumers.

title: A Vacuum in Japan
abstract: EVEN the most ardent critics of General MacArthur will admit that his removal creates a serious vacuum in Japan which, unless promptly filled, can endanger our future relations with that country. MacArthur was the symbol not only of the great power of the United States but of our abiding interests shared with the Japanese in economic, military, and political life.

title: Our Future and Japan's
abstract: WHATEVER may be our differences with respect to our commitments in Europe, there is little perceptible argument about the critical importance of making Japan strong enough to defend itself against the Communist tide. The issue now comes down to ways and means, for the rearmament of Japan requires more than an order from Washington.

title: The Right Above the Law
abstract: DEAN Clarence Manion of the Law School of the University of Notre Dame initiated in 1947 a project of the greatest national importance in these days of doubt, darkened outlook, and ideological conflict. There was held in that year the first convocation of an institute devoted to a discussion of the natural law and its bearing upon the problems of these days.

title: Voice of Moderation: Who's Who in Politics
abstract: IT is difficult to realize how firmly entrenched in this country are the forces which would pervert the free institutions of this country into the reality of a socialist state. The drift toward more state power, particularly Federal power, began many years ago under such names as "progressivism" or "liberalism.

title: Hunting the Thomas Scalp
abstract: OKLAHOMA CITY—If either of two very determined hunters has his way, the flowing white thatch of Sen. Elmer Thomas will be lifted this year. The first hunter will be Congressman Mike Monroney, and his attack will be in the Democratic primary on July 4. The second will probably be the Rev. W. H. (Bill) Alexander, the prospective Republican candidate in November.

title: Railroads in Strait Jackets
abstract: THE recent order of the Interstate Commerce Commission granting Eastern railroads a 12.5 per cent increase in passenger fares has been variously received. Some newspapers, widely read by grumbling commuters, have assailed the increase with suggestions indicating a feeling that they could run the railroads more profitably.

title: Feeding Hungry Horses
abstract: PORTLAND—One of the newest and biggest of the Federal projects that I have seen on this trip through the Northwest is at Hungry Horse, Mont., in the Flathead River Canyon. There in the early stages of construction is a dam which, it is said, will be the fourth largest in the United States.

title: The Iron Muzzle on the Great Lakes
abstract: DULUTH—Yesterday I drove through a region that the State of Michigan once accepted from Congress under violent protest. Tomorrow I shall cross an area that England ceded to the United States because the diplomats who wrote the Treaty of Paris in 1783 used a defective map. Together, these lands have provided the iron core of our industrial civilization.

title: The Race Narrows
abstract: DALLAS—In Texas, as elsewhere, the independents and some Republicans who were talking about Eisenhower are turning to Stassen in considerable numbers. The withdrawal of the general has also sharpened the contest between Taft and Dewey. Eisenhower's renunciation seemed inevitable for several weeks and was predicted by thoughtful people who preferred him for, President.

title: The Land Is Bright
abstract: PEORIA—A long automobile trip such as this observer is completing would, I am sure, be fatal to a professional viewer-with-alarm. He might survive the stress of spotty weather, crowded lodgings, highway reconstruction and high prices. But his nerves would crack before the indifference of the great American public to all warnings of perilous trends, of impending crises and of menacing doom.

title: Politics in Wisconsin and Minnesota
abstract: MINNEAPOLIS—At this late date, Harold Stassen is still the only frankly declared candidate for President. Another distinction he shares with Senator Taft. He is outspoken. People like him for that, although some of his friends in Minnesota feel he has said a few things which it would have been wiser to have left unsaid.

title: What Hague Has Joined Together
abstract: THE best ^political story I ever read is "Malachi Nolan," a short sketch by Brand Whitlock, who knew his Chicago, Springfield and Toledo. It portrays a ward boss who, in his mellow and opulent years, was persuaded by his daughter to quit and pay a visit to Limerick.

title: A Planned Economy for Germany
abstract: M uch as Americans may dislike tbe methods and implications of a planned economy, they will have to impose some such system upon tbe section of Germany that we shall occupy. We shall have to tell Germans where and when they may work, plant, reap, manufacture, trade, borrow, lend and travel.

title: World Order Under Law
abstract: In the Crimean statement appears a pledge of the Big Three to build "world order under law." This is not a mere rhetorical flourish or an empty expression of political theory. It is a basic concept whose light must guide even' step now taken from San Francisco onward.

title: No More Parades?
abstract: Several weeks ago, but since Pearl Harbor, I had occasion to speak to a group of college students, men and women. Questions followed—questions that made it clear that these young people were not taking apathetically a situation in which they would be bearing the biggest load. That was good.

title: The Citizen Meets the Crisis
abstract: Now that close to two weeks of war have passed into history, it is possible to take stock of our national state of mind. How have we done? Fairly well, on the morale side. Fairly well, in the sense that there has been no panic, no hysteria and an instant closing of ranks among all sorts and conditions of people.

title: Premature Obituary No. 1
abstract: Probably the most appealing of all popular ideas about politics is the notion that a major party which has had a few reverses at the polls can be killed off, "rehabilitated," reconstituted, or what have you. It is also the most deceptive, as well-meaning political innocents are going to find out before a year has passed.

title: Something About Intolerance
abstract: This little piece about intolerance is not written with any conviction that it can have much influence, because it is written at a moment when feelings are getting so ruffled that no preachment can help much. And this is not even a preachment; it is just a quiet observation of fact. Respect for the other fellow's right to speak his mind, as a political policy, only partly rests upon moral grounds.

title: 'Inflation-Conscious'
abstract: On January 11, 1941, Leon Henderson of the OPACS and my colleague Ralph Robey, of NEWSWEEK, participated in the radio program, The People's Platform. The subject was inflation. Pointing out the certain danger of inflation, Mr. Robey pressed Mr. Henderson to express his views. Mr. Henderson was not so alarmed: "... we are not threatened with inflation at the present time," he said.

title: Four Choices
abstract: Foreign Minister Eden's latest speeches on world policy are among the many pieces of evidence that informed people expect, another peace offensive from Hitler before very long. Those who believe this feel that Hitler will offer unexpectedly mild terms to Great Britain. Whether these terms should so much as be considered would theoretically, at least, be a matter for the British to decide without backseat driving from us.

title: 'We Hold These Truths'
abstract: The United States was not created in a day. The gestation of its nationality covered twenty years. Historians agree that the violent imperial clash between France and England which made a battlefield of America taught the colonies the importance of sticking to one another long before the Seven Years' War ended in 1763.

title: Life Insurance and the TNEC
abstract: Holders of life-insurance policies have a right to be perplexed by the news out of Washington last week. First there were the stories of a huge report on insurance—heralded by papers the country over with such headlines as "U. S. Control of Insurance Urged on TNEC," "What's Wrong With Insurance? Here Are the Answers From an SEC Report." These were accompanied by the announcement that the authors of the report, Gerhard A. Gesell and Ernest J. Howe, were speaking neither for the SEC nor for the Temporary National Economic (Monopoly) Committee.

title: Mr. Wallace
abstract: Americans have cherished the Vice Presidency chiefly as a source of innocent merriment. But the joke—if they persist in the whimsy—is on them. Of 25 individuals elected to the Presidency by the people, six have been succeeded by the Vice President elected with them—a fairly large proportion, all things considered.

title: The New Axis
abstract: for Americans, the Japanese-German-Italian agreement provides the most frightening news since the war began. But it can have its uses. First, it can force us to concentrate upon that irreducible minimum of what we must defend in order to protect our own country. Second, it can open our eyes to what our diplomacy and laggard defense have exposed us.

title: Mr. Garner's Silence
abstract: If tears were shed by any of Vice President Garner's friends as he left Washington last week, they should have been tears of regret over what they had done to themselves at Chicago, the week before, and not tears for him. "Daughters of Jerusalem, ... weep for yourselves," he might have told them. For Mr. Garner leaves with his laurels, his conscience and the assurance that he closes the books of official life with his principles unimpaired.

title: Antidotes to Pessimism
abstract: For us Americans there could be few better antidotes to pessimism at this moment than two magnificent books just published. One is a warning, and the other, a promise. One is the study of the progress of a mortal politico-economic disease, and the other, a study of our political economy's capacity for resisting it.

title: An Expensive Bargain
abstract: The President's new relief request suggests the technique of the bargain counter. Good merchandisers know all about the pulling power of the 98-cent article as against the $1 article. The sum of $975,000,000 is what the President asks to spend for WPA. Think of how nice to say in the campaign:

title: Bricker of Ohio
abstract: Babes in the political woods have been calling Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio a dark horse for some twelve months now. He isn't, of course. To begin with, nobody's a dark horse who's been called a dark horse for a year. Dark horses aren't talked about as such before the eventful moment of their nomination. But more to the point is the fact that no Republican Governor of Ohio was ever a dark horse at a Republican convention.

title: The Law Is to Blame
abstract: When in the haste, heat and hatred of the summer of 1935, Congress threw together and passed the National Labor Relations Act, many cool-headed people said that Congress would be sorry. The House, at any rate, seemed sorry when, four years later, in a calmer moment, it ordered the current investigation of the NLRB.

title: No 'Prejudism'
abstract: "Let there be no prejudism," bellowed the announcer when, on a June night three years ago, Joe Louis and Max Schmeling began their first fight. There was none. Millions in New York kept their heads and restrained their passions. They observed the announcer's quaint call for fair play and no street brawls.

title: Stop, Look and Then Listen
abstract: I wish there were someone wise enough to formulate some rules that might be called "First Aid for Listeners of War News" for the use of Americans these nights when they're beginning to stay home and listen to the radio. The rules ought to be printed in red type, neatly framed and hung up in clear sight of the family.

title: Perspective: The President and Congress
abstract: As Congress assembles this week, the immediate order of business is the proposed repeal of the arms embargo. But the fundamental issues during the session will lie deeper, for the arms-embargo question is merely a symbol. It is the President's intention to have Congress amend the Neutrality Act and then adjourn.

title: Let Them In
abstract: Apparently our big, brave American Congress, representing the richest, the most powerful and reputedly the most generous nation in the world, is groveling before the prospect of a peaceful invasion by 20,000 children. The Wagner-Rogers Bill seems to be stuck in the House Committee on Immigration and to have been reported out of the Senate Committee with vitiating amendments, despite the support and despite the moving pleas of the representatives of nonpartisan organizations and of great religious, educational and social agencies.

title: Perspective: Frustration
abstract: This session of Congress must be written down as a session of fumbled opportunity. The blame for the futile regular session of 1937 lay chiefly with the President, whose stubborn insistence upon the enactment of his Court-packing plan gave Congress no alternative but to neglect constructive efforts and devote itself to equally stubborn resistance.

title: Drifting Toward War
abstract: For weeks it has been known that certain internationalists and "intellectuals" in and around the State Department and in New York City have been getting ready for a mighty drive to "educate" American public opinion to favor the alignment of the United States with "democratic" powers against Japan, Germany and Italy (Periscope, Feb. 14).

title: Five Years—an Inventory
abstract: This week sees the fifth anniversary of the day that Mr. Roosevelt began his attempt to put into operation a progressive redefinition of the aims of modern democratic government. Progressivism did not begin in 1933: the New Deal, as Franklin Roosevelt defined it, was in essence T.R.'s Square Deal modified and corrected in the light of twenty years of change; it was a synthesis of the principles of men who had fought in the cities, the states and the nation for the liberalization of our economic life.

title: Housing at Last?
abstract: The efforts to encourage more private home building now germinating in Washington recall a bit of personal history. I hope that the presumption of narrating it may, in all the circumstances, be pardoned. It had become perfectly obvious in the second half of 1934 that the initial impulse toward recovery induced by the measures of 1933 was slowing up.

title: SHOP TALK
abstract: Seven months ago the magazines TODAY and NEWSWEEK were merged. The purpose of the merger was to consolidate the editorial ideals of both magazines in a new synthesis of news, interpretation and opinion. The difficult task of achieving this fusion of policies has now been accomplished.

title: The Duty to be Neutral
abstract: Three separate and distinct times in the past four years, the State Department asked Congress, in effect, to be allowed to choose between nations engaged in foreign war upon the basis of a moral judgment as to the right and wrong of the quarrel. Three separate and distinct times Congress refused to grant that power and, speaking for the American people, announced a policy of impartiality with reference to warring nations.

title: Frankfurter Rumors
abstract: The Washington rumor factory is turning out a new 1937 Frankfurter model: the Professor has "broken" with the President. The 1935 Frankfurter model produced by the same factory made him out to be a hidden potentate—running the United States from an untidy desk in the dusty stacks of the Harvard Law Library.

title: Sawing the Party in Two
abstract: WHOLLY aside from the effect of the President's letter to Senator Barkley on the battle for party leadership in the Senate, the letter is an historic document, the symbol of a political crisis whose outcome will shape the affairs of government for years to come.
